summary: This is a legal opinion from French attorney William Julie, dated December 18, 2020, submitted in opposition to the U.S. government's memorandum regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's potential extradition. The opinion analyzes French extradition law, the U.S.-France Extradition Treaty, and refutes the government's reliance on the 2007 Peterson case to argue France would not extradite Maxwell.

persons.name: William Julie
persons.context: Author of the legal opinion analyzing French extradition law and arguing against the U.S. government's position that France would not extradite Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the potential extradition request from the United States to France. The legal opinion argues it is highly unlikely France would refuse to extradite her.

persons.name: Hans Peterson
persons.context: A dual citizen whose extradition from France to the U.S. was denied in 2007. The U.S. government cited this case as a precedent; William Julie argues it is not a valid legal precedent.

persons.name: Richard J. Durbin
persons.context: Co-authored a 2007 letter with Barack Obama to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs regarding the Peterson extradition case, urging France to exercise discretion in favor of extradition.

persons.name: Barack Obama
persons.context: Co-authored a 2007 letter with Richard J. Durbin to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs regarding the Peterson extradition case.

connections.description: William Julie is providing a legal opinion on behalf of Maxwell's defense, analyzing the likelihood of her extradition from France.
Collaborated as U.S. Senators in 2007 to send a joint letter to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs regarding the Peterson extradition case.
The U.S. government sought Peterson's extradition from France in 2007, which was denied by the French Ministry of Justice.

events.title: France Refuses Peterson Extradition
events.description: The French Minister of Justice communicated a decision refusing the U.S. request to extradite dual citizen Hans Peterson.

events.title: Durbin-Obama Letter to France
events.description: U.S. Senators Richard J. Durbin and Barack Obama sent a letter to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs urging France to exercise discretion in favor of extraditing nationals to the U.S.

events.title: EU-U.S. Extradition Agreement Enters Force
events.description: The Agreement on extradition between the European Union and the United States of America came into force, enhancing cooperation.

events.title: French Minister of Justice Letter
events.description: The French Minister of Justice issued a letter (Exhibit B) cited by the U.S. government arguing France does not extradite its citizens outside the EU.

keyFacts: The legal opinion argues the key question is whether France may extradite a French national under the U.S.-France Extradition Treaty, not under French domestic law alone.

The opinion contends the 2007 Peterson case is not a valid legal precedent because it was a discretionary ministerial decision, not a published judicial ruling, and the U.S. did not challenge the refusal in French courts.
Article 3 of the U.S.-France Extradition Treaty gives France discretion, but does not preclude, the extradition of its own citizens to the U.S.
The opinion states that if Ghislaine Maxwell signed an irrevocable waiver in the U.S., it is 'highly unlikely' the French government would refuse to extradite her.
The 2010 EU-U.S. Extradition Agreement must be considered in any modern extradition request, which post-dates the Peterson case.
